dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Russian trade policy is completely ignoring the Real Effective Exchange Rate, but that's actually a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Russian trade policy is completely ignoring the Real Effective Exchange Rate, but that's actually a huge problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they're doing it with outdated methods that assume countries only import final goods, which just isn't true anymore with all these protectionist measures popping up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they're doing it with outdated methods that assume countries only import final goods, which just isn't true anymore with all these protectionist measures popping up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Standard calculations of the REER by most central banks and statistical agencies assume that countries export only final goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Like, take the U.S. slapping a 50% tariff on oil imports—that totally disrupts traditional supply chain assumptions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Like, take the U.S. slapping a fifty percent tariff on oil imports-that totally disrupts traditional supply chain assumptions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The preliminary U.S. decision to apply 25% tariffs on steel imports and 10%...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: And the example with electric cars is so telling. If Germany makes the parts and ships them to the U.S., but then the cars get dismantled and re-exported... standard REER models would totally misread the competitiveness impact of, say, a euro depreciation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the example with electric cars is so telling. If Germany makes the parts and ships them to the U.S., but then the cars get dismantled and re-exported... standard R E E R models would totally misread the competitiveness impact of, say, a euro depreciation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To see how the standard approach could be wrong, consider a hypothetical value chain for the production of smartphones. Suppose Japan manufactures the components and ships them to China, where the phones are assembled and exported globally as finished products.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: They'd think a weaker euro helps Germany's exports, but in this fragmented supply chain, it might actually hurt U.S. competitiveness if German parts get more expensive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They'd think a weaker euro helps Germany's exports, but in this fragmented supply chain, it might actually hurt U.S. competitiveness if German parts get more expensive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In this case, however, a weaker yen would lower the price of Japanese components, which may lead to lower prices and increased demand for Chinese phones leading to an improvement in Chinas competitiveness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Which is why the proposed new framework by, uh, Nikhil Patel and Shang-Jin Wei is so important. It tries to account for these production stages spread across borders.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is why the proposed new framework by, uh, Nikhil Patel and Shang-Jin Wei is so important. It tries to account for these production stages spread across borders.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We therefore recently proposed a new REER calculation with Zhi Wang that addresses the current shortcomings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: And it even changes how we see something like China's exchange rate. Most people think the yuan is way undervalued, but this new method suggests it might have actually depreciated slightly against the dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it even changes how we see something like China's exchange rate. Most people think the yuan is way undervalued, but this new method suggests it might have actually depreciated slightly against the dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once these factors are taken into account, our analysis shows that Chinas real exchange rate against the US dollar displays a pronounced and consistent appreciation trend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Because China operates upstream in so many supply chains, right? Like in vehicles and machinery—a lot of what looks like Chinese imports is actually value added from China itself embedded in components.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because China operates upstream in so many supply chains, right? Like in vehicles and machinery-a lot of what looks like Chinese imports is actually value added from China itself embedded in components.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Chinas gross exports to the US are sizeable, China operates largely downstream in several GVCs. This is exemplified in the production of smartphones and electronic goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, U.S. competitiveness against China depends more on non-tradable sectors, like real estate, which aggregate REER measures totally miss.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, U.S. competitiveness against China depends more on non-tradable sectors, like real estate, which aggregate R E E R measures totally miss.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, US competitiveness relative to China depends more on prices in tradable sectors such as electronics than on those in non-tradable parts of the economy, like real estate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: And look at the eurozone example—Greece's competitiveness before the crisis was actually better than the standard REER suggested, because the old model overestimated inflation differences due to protectionist barriers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And look at the eurozone example-Greece's competitiveness before the crisis was actually better than the standard R E E R suggested, because the old model overestimated inflation differences due to protectionist barriers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, for the eurozone, our GVC exchange-rate-based measure implies that Greeces loss of competitiveness (or REER appreciation) relative to Germany was worse than the standard measure suggests, and that Greeces competitiveness in the period leading up to the eurozone crisis was thus worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: So these miscalculations aren't just academic; they can lead to some really misguided policy decisions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So these miscalculations aren't just academic; they can lead to some really misguided policy decisions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Calculating it more accurately could reduce the risk of misguided economic policies. And it may lead policymakers to reach some very different conclusions about which measures to pursue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. If central banks and financial institutions keep using the old methods, they might draw the wrong conclusions about which sectors need support or what tariffs to impose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. If central banks and financial institutions keep using the old methods, they might draw the wrong conclusions about which sectors need support or what tariffs to impose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the REERs importance for economic policy in the current trade discussions between the United States and China, for example central banks and international financial institutions devote considerable resources to calculating and analyzing it. But their methods have become outdated as global value chains (GVCs) become increasingly widespread.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild that something as technical as the REER could have such real-world impact, but here we are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild that something as technical as the R E E R could have such real-world impact, but here we are.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Far from being a theoretical concept confined to economics textbooks, the REER has significant real-world relevance.

artist_script:
Russian trade policy is completely ignoring the Real Effective Exchange Rate, but that's actually a huge problem.
Right, and they're doing it with outdated methods that assume countries only import final goods, which just isn't true anymore with all these protectionist measures popping up.
Exactly. Like, take the U.S. slapping a 50% tariff on oil imports—that totally disrupts traditional supply chain assumptions.
And the example with electric cars is so telling. If Germany makes the parts and ships them to the U.S., but then the cars get dismantled and re-exported... standard REER models would totally misread the competitiveness impact of, say, a euro depreciation.
They'd think a weaker euro helps Germany's exports, but in this fragmented supply chain, it might actually hurt U.S. competitiveness if German parts get more expensive.
Which is why the proposed new framework by, uh, Nikhil Patel and Shang-Jin Wei is so important. It tries to account for these production stages spread across borders.
And it even changes how we see something like China's exchange rate. Most people think the yuan is way undervalued, but this new method suggests it might have actually depreciated slightly against the dollar.
Because China operates upstream in so many supply chains, right? Like in vehicles and machinery—a lot of what looks like Chinese imports is actually value added from China itself embedded in components.
Plus, U.S. competitiveness against China depends more on non-tradable sectors, like real estate, which aggregate REER measures totally miss.
And look at the eurozone example—Greece’s competitiveness before the crisis was actually better than the standard REER suggested, because the old model overestimated inflation differences due to protectionist barriers.
So these miscalculations aren't just academic; they can lead to some really misguided policy decisions.
Exactly. If central banks and financial institutions keep using the old methods, they might draw the wrong conclusions about which sectors need support or what tariffs to impose.
It’s wild that something as technical as the REER could have such real-world impact, but here we are.
